column1: . [SEP] The result is beautiful, but has two problems. [SEP] First, Feynman assumes a continuous background space and time in his theory. [SEP] Quantum gravity, as we will see, cannot make that assumption in the first place. [SEP] Rather space, or geometry, is a discrete, self-constructing object on its own. [SEP] Thus, achieving a smooth space and time is supposed to be a consequence of an adequate theory of quantum gravity. [SEP] If Feynman’s sum over histories must assume a smooth background space and time, then it cannot as such be taken as primitive in quantum gravity. [SEP] Second, granting a continuous background space and time, Feynman’s sum over all histories still only gives a maximum of the amplitude for the photon to travel the classical pathway, it never gives an actual photon
column3: at the counting surface. [SEP] No more than any other does Feynman overcome the fundamental linearity of quantum mechanics. [SEP] We still have to collapse the wave function. [SEP] Despite these problems, Feynman’s results are brilliant, and at least we see a link between the classical and quantum worlds, if not yet actual photons striking counters. [SEP] But there is an alternative approach to the link between the quantum and the classical worlds. [SEP] This possible approach is based on the well-established phenomenon of “decoherence.” [SEP] Decoherence arises when a quantum-coherent Schrödinger wave is propagating and the quantum system interacts with another quantum system having many coupled variables, or degrees of freedom. [SEP] The consequence can be that the Schrödinger wave functi

column1: Arguably James Clerk Maxwell was the greatest scientist of the nineteenth century, notwithstanding giants such as Carnot, Boltzmann, and Darwin. [SEP] While his most radical work is captured in the Maxwell equations for electromagnetic fields, which introduced the fundamental concept of fields into physics, Maxwell concerned himself deeply with the puzzle Carnot had raised in what is now called the second law of thermodynamics. [SEP] Consider again a thermodynamically isolated system. [SEP] That is, consider some box containing a gas, isolated from any change in its energy or mass
column3: from the outside. [SEP] There are N gas particles in the box, and as noted earlier, we can consider the positions and momenta of all N particles. [SEP] Each position and each momentum can be decomposed into three numbers defining position and motion in the three spatial directions. [SEP] Hence, the entire state of the N particles of gas can be defined by N numbers, plus a specification of the interior boundaries of the box. [SEP] As described above, all the possible states of this N system of particles can be divided into very small volumes of states, which we will call microstates. [SEP] Again, as noted in chapter , a macrostate is a collection of microstates. [SEP] In particular, the equilibrium macrostate is a collection of microstates having the property that the gas particles are nearl

column1: All of which brings us, inevitably, to the brink of semantics. [SEP] It is simple at its roots, you see. [SEP] An incoming molecular species
column3: in the interior of an autonomous agent really is [SEP] (i) food; [SEP] (ii) poison; [SEP] (iii) a signal; [SEP] (iv) neutral; [SEP] (v) something else. [SEP] Once there is an autonomous agent, there is a semantics from its privileged point of view. [SEP] The incoming molecule is “yuck” or “yum.” [SEP] I think the major conceptual step to yuck or yum is unavoidable once there is an autonomous agent. [SEP] And I think we have roughly the Darwinian criteria in mind. [SEP] If yum, then there will probably be more of this type of agent, osprings of the first. [SEP] If yuck, it is not so likely this lineage will prosper.

column1: ble to calculate the mutual information, MI, between pairs of the M action states. [SEP] MI is H(A) + H(B) - H(AB). [SEP] Here H(A) is the entropy of A, H(B) the entropy of B, and H (AB) is the joint entropy of A and B. If A and B are occurring randomly with respect to one another, then H(AB) equals the sum of H(A) + H(B), so MI is . [SEP] If either A or B is unchanging, MI is again . [SEP] But if A and B are changing in correlated ways, MI is positive. [SEP] Hence, we can ask what value of M maximizes the mutual information among the M states, how is that related to cell and community position on the edge-of-chaos phase transition in Figure . [SEP] , and how well does the mutual information among the M action states correlate with the mutual information in the patterns of CS input signals
column3: at each cell type? [SEP] More broadly, can selection maximize both M and that mutual information correlation and, if so, for what value of M and where on or o the phase transition surface in Figure . [SEP] ? I do not know the answers but hope the optimal point lies on the phase transition surface, for such selected mutual information correlation would begin to show that such communities of cells with such regulatory networks can indeed make the maximum number of reliable discriminations and act on them without trembling hands to make a complex living in a complex world.

column3: at the Emma E. Booker Elementary School, where President Bush was to read to a class and talk about education. [SEP] White House Chief of Staff Andrew Card told us he was standing with the President outside the classroom when Senior Advisor to the President Karl Rove first informed them that a small, twin-engine plane had crashed into the World Trade Center. [SEP] The President's reaction was that the incident must have been caused by pilot error. [SEP] At 8:55, before entering the classroom, the President spoke to National Security Advisor Condoleezza Rice, who was at the White House. [SEP] She recalled first telling the President it was a twin-engine aircraft-and then a commercial aircraft-that had struck the World Trade Center, adding "that's all we know right now, Mr. President."

column1: ermuda’s growing tourist industry all but collapsed. [SEP] The ships were commandeered to carry troops or become floating hospitals, and the waters around the islands were infested with German submarines. [SEP] Bermuda played an important role in intelligence. [SEP] In the basements of the Princess and Bermudiana hotels, more than a thousand British experts analyzed communications intercepted between the western hemisphere and Europe. [SEP] Mail quietly removed from refueling ships and planes was steamed open and tested for microdots and invisible codes, an important contribution to the struggle against Axis spying activity. [SEP] The big hotels stayed in business by serving as billets for servicemen and civilian war workers. [SEP] Just as the first British M15 intelligence operatives were
column3: in Hamilton in August 1940, the Lend-Lease Act was negotiated between Britain and the US. [SEP] Under a 99-year lease, the US acquired about one-tenth of the land area of Bermuda for the development of naval and air bases, modernizing the defenses of Britain’s “Gibraltar of the West.” [SEP] Changing Times

column1: Postwar, the British military presence dwindled, and the main sections of the dockyard were closed in 1951. [SEP] They were deserted for a number of years before being brought to life as a tourist attraction. [SEP] Today, the Royal Naval Dockyard, on Ireland Island North, has been reborn with a number of sights and activities. [SEP] You could certainly spend a morning or an afternoon exploring here. [SEP] Start your tour at the Bermuda Maritime Museum, opened in 1975 by Queen Elizabeth II. [SEP] If traveling by bus (Routes [SEP]7 or [SEP]8), you will alight at the last stop;
column3: by ferry, you should turn right from the ferry port and follow the footpath around the dock, where you will see the walls of the central fortress (or “keep”) rising in front of you. [SEP] The museum is entered through a large archway beyond a moat. [SEP] It covers 21⁄2 hectares (6 acres), and various collections are housed in the old brick military buildings, most of which date from the Victorian era. [SEP] Where ordnance was once stored there are now collections of coins and treasure salvaged from the ocean floor. [SEP] You will also find displays of diving equipment used over the centuries to explore the shipwrecks that can be found all around the treacherous reefs off the coast here. [SEP] The Boat Loft houses a collection reflecting Bermuda’s innovative local designs, including a fully

column1: armly. [SEP] In later centuries the islanders’ gracious hospitality was to cost them dearly. [SEP] Europeans did not arrive until the 14th century, when the Genoese sailor Lanzarotto Marcello colonized the island, known then in native tongue as Tytheroygatra and subsequently as Lanzarote. [SEP] Slave traders, treasure seekers, and missionaries all followed in Lanzarotto’s wake, but it was not until 1402 that the European conquest of the Canaries began in earnest. [SEP] At its helm was the Norman baron, Jean de Béthencourt, under service to Henry III, king of Castile. [SEP] After the baron had taken Lanzarote and Fuerteventura with comparative ease, his ships were scattered by storms off Gran Canaria. [SEP] He next turned to El Hierro, where the awestruck islanders welcomed the new visitors
column3: in their great floating vessels as gods. [SEP] Béthencourt returned the hospitality by inviting the natives aboard his ships. [SEP] He then took them captive and sold them into slavery. [SEP] Around this time the Portuguese, who had also been colonizing the Atlantic, turned their attention to the Canaries. [SEP] Naval skirmishes ensued between the two powers, but at the end of the war of succession between Portugal and Castile, the wide-ranging Treaty of Alcaçovas ended Lisbon’s claims to the Fortunate Islands.

column1: Laguna de Medina Across the Guadalquivir and just about 10 km (6 miles) east of Jerez de la Frontera is this small lake, one of the last stops in Europe for birds migrating south from northern and central Europe to Africa at the end of August. [SEP] In periods of drought it is attractive to birds that usually reside at Doñana, and around 50 species have been observed here. [SEP] Grazalema A short distance to the east of Laguna de Medina is the mainly mountain wilderness of the natural park of Grazalema. [SEP] Its 51,695 hectares (127,740 acres) are home to three species of eagles and numerous other birds, mammals, and reptiles. [SEP] Interestingly, the mountains here, which range between 1,000 and 1,700 meters (3,300 and 5,600 ft), are the first stop for clouds
column3: from the Atlantic, giving the area the greatest annual rainfall in Spain. [SEP] This allows a fine array of flora to thrive. [SEP] Of particular note is the rare abies pinsapo (Spanish fir tree). [SEP] El Torcal de Antequera and the Fuente de Piedra Just south of the city of Antequera is one of the more famous geological formations in Spain. [SEP] The limestone mountains of the El Torcal de Antequera have eroded to form some of the most unusual shapes seen anywhere. [SEP] In fact, these formations so resemble modern sculptures that they have been assigned comical names. [SEP] Just north of Antequera, droughts notwithstanding, is the Fuente de Piedra, Andalucía’s largest lake, with a surface area that can reach 1,384 hectares (3,420 acres). [SEP] Each spring, provided that weather conditions

column1: ense of privacy; however, to date, it offers little in the way of dining, shopping, or nightlife outside the hotels. [SEP] A new festival shopping center, slated to open in the summer of 2000, should increase these options, and transportation into Puerto Vallarta — about 30 minutes by taxi — is readily available. [SEP] Nuevo Vallarta is also the place to kayak a lagoon or swim with dolphins. [SEP] Located just north of downtown, Marina Vallarta is the site of modern hotels and wide beaches. [SEP] It is a resort within a resort, with a championship golf course, ample tennis facilities, and an exclusive marina filled with yachts, sailing vessels, and charter boats. [SEP] Surrounding the marina are numerous boutiques, restaurants, and travel agencies, plus all types of services to accommodate
column3: cruisers. [SEP] Condominiums, many available for vacation rental, surround the marina as well. [SEP] This fashionable neighborhood is a favorite with families, and offers the best array of activities and entertainment for the younger traveler — including a water park and mammoth video arcade and entertainment center. [SEP] Since this development sits on a swampy area that has been filled in, the beaches in Marina Vallarta are less attractive than those in other areas of town, and are occasionally very rocky. [SEP] The grand hotels make up for this with their dazzling pools, but anyone whose heart is set on true “beach time” should consider another option.
